content.title: Endoleak Classification and Management
content.definition: Persistent blood flow outside the endograft lumen but within the aneurysm sac following endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR or TEVAR). Endoleaks prevent complete aneurysm exclusion and may lead to continued aneurysm pressurization, growth, and rupture.

type_I.definition: Attachment site leak - blood flow at proximal (Ia) or distal (Ib) seal zones
type_I.significance: High pressure, direct systemic flow - REQUIRES TREATMENT
type_I.natural_history: Will NOT seal spontaneously, leads to sac expansion

type_II.definition: Branch vessel retrograde flow into sac

type_IV.significance: Rare with modern grafts, no treatment needed

type_V.definition: Endotension - sac expansion without visible endoleak

delayed_phase.role: Distinguish Type I/III from Type II

type_II.treatment_indications: Sac growth >5mm, persistent >6 months with growth

content.statement: Endoleak Classification and Management is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Complications that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Endoleak Classification and Management helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Endoleak Classification and Management include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Endoleak Classification and Management.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity
definitions_glossary.relationship: A connection or association between concepts

learning_objectives: Classify endoleaks by type and clinical significance
Apply appropriate surveillance and treatment algorithms
Recognize when observation vs intervention is appropriate
clinical_pearls: Type I and III are HIGH PRESSURE - always treat
Type II is LOW PRESSURE - observe unless sac growing
Delayed phase CT distinguishes Type I/III (early fill) from Type II (delayed fill)
50% of Type II endoleaks seal spontaneously within 6 months
Sac growth without visible endoleak = Type V (endotension)
evidence_basis: Society for Vascular Surgery Practice Guidelines

sources.source: UpToDate. (2024). Endoleak Classification and Management. Wolters Kluwer.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
